Kept her awake, long enough for Siobhan to come with a doctor.  Have to ask her sometime how she managed that - couldn't have been gone ten minutes.  Maybe a neighbor.  Maybe she just willed it so.  But we got her bandaged and stitched and put her to bed, and then I went about the house doing what was necessary with salt and iron nails.  He may be angry - let him rail.  He's not getting in this house again.

So it's a relief, then.  We've torn open the wound, sure enough, and now we have to scoop out the sick and the rot that's been festering within all this while, and it's going to hurt.  And that's my doing, which accounts for the pride.  The shame in my heart is that I let it get this far, the silence and the secrets.  I let myself forget that Rabbit is strong-willed and secretive, and that Siobhan is bull-headed and a sight more intelligent than she lets on.  And I never knew the depths in either of 'em - that the faeries came to Siobhan first of all of us and she rejected them, or just how far from our good Earth Rabbit can go, how very powerful she is.  I thought she'd learned her lesson from Ian.  Did I do wrong, to forgive her?  Where are you now, brother - are you at peace, or do you rage at the family that left you behind, bargained you away for the life of one nameless soldier?

I can't not forgive her.  Don't know that it's wise, but there it is.  She's my sister and beneath it all she's still a wee slip of a girl, lost, frightened.  I'll not drive her away.  Couldn't if I wanted.  Either of them.  

Which is why I hurt, come to that.  Do they, I wonder, agonize over unkind things said, as I do?  I know what they think of me - Will the happy, lazy drunk.  Both of 'em giving me grief for drinking two and a half glasses of whiskey.  If they only knew what I give up for them, how often I've wanted to tear into the night, get lost in the haze and magic warmth of the pub, forget all my troubles.  Not once since Galway, and have they noticed?  Have they bollocks.

Dark thoughts for such a bright day - and this evening will be hard enough without me dwelling on slights.  Still, I wish...

No.  It is what it is.

I am in a blind bloody rage.  I have to get this out of me and on to cool stark paper or I'll start smashing china, and I don't think I want to drive Siobhan round the bend again so soon.

We've moved into our new house and found it haunted.  Can't rightly say why I even bother to be surprised.  Time to time I wonder if some warlock back in Eire laid a curse on the May family.  Not as though anyone'd bother to tell me if they did; there'd just be significant looks and cryptic comments and no one ever giving me a straight fecking answer.

I thought I had it figured.  Well, not figured, but I was sure that the locket was the key to the mystery - Siobhan, or whatever was riding around in Siobhan's skin for the past day and a half, was obsessed with it.  Well, whatever it was a key to, the lock's been taken away.  I helped her move the bed to where she saw the spirit and settled down to wait, sure that she'd come for the locket before long.  Wrong, wrong, wrong.  A thump and a few minutes and she's right back to her old self, harping on me to move the bed back, thank you very much, and bawling me out for breaking the door - which she has no memory of, by the bye.

So it's done.  Nothing.  No answers, no solved mystery, it just faded away.  Sure, and I'm pleased to have our house be our house - the thought of getting a good night's sleep fills me with no small measure of pleasure.  And aye, there is some pride in knowing that we endured and won through.  But every man I spoke to of ghosts said what I already believed - if there's spirits chained to the Earth then they need our help to go on.  Did we help them?  I fear not.  I certainly didn't.  Siobhan was too crazed to do much other than mutter and fret, and I can't bring myself to accept that the earthbound dead can be released by rearranging the furniture.  <strike>Rabb</strike> Eileen, now...well, she may have done something, sure enough.  But she's not been overly subtle when it comes to weilding her...influence.  And it'd be a fine thing if she had done something and not told me.  Such as inviting the preist over without a by-your-leave.  Ah, I shouldn't accuse her, not when I've nothing but suspicion and bitterness in my heart.

What drives me mad is the attitude my sisters take to the whole affair.  Eileen seems to care for nothing else other than it's over, and Siobhan refuses to believe any of it, despite the evidence before her face.  How can they be so completely incurious?  Why were the ghosts here?  Why have they gone?  Are they truly at rest now?  Are there any yet living that could tell us - or that might have to answer for - what happened in this house?  Ugh - it's enough to make me want to shake them.

This is not over.  I have the artifacts of the restless dead and some ideas of where to look next.  I will find the truth and I will ensure that it will not go unremembered.  

I feel calmer, a bit, but the anger that filled my heart has given way to pain.  There's a wrongness here.  There's secrets and silence.  Is this what we came to America for, to drift apart and become strangers to each other?  I've kept things from my sisters to keep them from worry or hurt, and now I come to question that.  Perhaps it's better to have all out in the open.  Maybe it's worth the risk.  

At least I have seeing Moira again to look forward to.

Nothing.  Don't know rightly what I was expecting - some touch of the infinite, some sign that someone or something out there is listening.  Instead I felt like a bit of a tit wandering about in a churchyard in the middle of the night to no real purpose.  Serves me right for begging gods for answers to things I should by rights deal with on my own.  Then again, <strike>Rabbi</strike> Eileen does seem a mite better lately.  Not everything has to have the bang and clash of portent, Will.

In no wise should I be up at this hour.  I seem to be having another episode wherein I fear for my sanity.

This evening Eileen suffered the Curse for the first time.  She's in no small amount of pain.  Breaks my heart.  I feel something between a brother and a father about her, and her childhood is coming to an end.  She's growing up, is our little Rabbit, and part of that means secrets - she'll not tell me everything any more.  Saddening to any elder brother's heart, but in her it's terrifying.  I may not be able to find a pet rabbit in a barn, but I watch people close, sure enough - when the wind blows north by northeast I can tell a hawk from a handsaw.  And I can tell that Rabbit has a witching way about her.  She sees things, she can make things happen, for good or ill.  I won't sleep well at night not knowing what's in her heart.  

I wonder...and I hate myself a little for not wondering sooner...what Siobhan thinks of all this.  True enough that we've dissembled on some matters, her ways are not the old ways, after all, and there's no point in telling her of bloody deeds done by moonlight.  But she felt it last night, as well.  I wondered...no.  There was no sound.  I'm sure of that much.  Rabbit woke, and then I did, and then Siobhan.  Did she realize there was no earthly reason for us two to be shocked out of a sound slumber?  I think...I think she had another of her night-terrors.  She was hurting, I know, but she couldn't stop scratching at her neck...and she'd that wide eyed fear of going back to sleep that I remember from when she was a child.  I imagine...yes, she's still sitting there, not moving, just staring.

Something's wrong inside, and I don't know how to fix any of this, how it all works.  They told me I'd find out, but I've been thrown in an ocean of chaos and I'm drowning.  I've felt the Power.  It touched me tonight and wakened me.  Yesterday it gave me the strength to work after I felt I'd nothing left, borne on the wings of black men's songs.  I wonder if faiths aren't made so as to fill the hole of what's wanting - the wild and free faeries for my crushed and subjugated people, the Christian love and forgiveness for those that can't even love and forgive them as believe in the same god, the vast comfort of the faith of slaves and sons of slaves.

Is anything true?  Have I not one solid place to stand?  Are there as many gods as men?  

I prayed tonight.  I've got out of the habit, somehow - praying in church is rote enough that I get pulled back into my own head and explore some other world behind my eyes.  I wish I knew the rituals.  Not knowing who best to ask, I prayed to Danu the Mother to ease Eileen's journey of becoming.  Just seemed the thing to do, somehow.

Possibility, possibility.  I come from a land where there's none to be found for love nor money, and now there's so much it freezes me to the spot.  Of course, the freezing might be due to standing in the icy waters of the harbour for nine cursed hours today.  My hands are screaming for rest and I'm nodding off from one word to the next but I can't stop writing.  I promised.  And even if I hadn't sworn it'd make no difference.  "The unexamined life is not worth living."  Who said that?  Socrates?  One of those Greeks, anyhow, I can never tell them apart.  Declan'd have my hide for that.  Whoever he truly is.

The introduction to the Order was not as I expected.  Not sure if that'd be from too many penny dreadfuls in Galway or that trip to Breaghwy, but I'd been thinking it would be a sight more gothic, with robes and bonfires and athames and all.  I can't bring myself to accept a secret society that worries about St. Patrick's Day cakes months ahead of time.  Now that I think on it, though, I remember something Katherine mentioned in passing - that we were being brought into the first circle of the Order.  Which leads me to believe that there's other circles - god only knows how many.  Could be that the Order we now know is only a cat's paw for something greater.  Could be I'm getting a bit too romantic for my own damn good.

I'm getting a wee bit itchy.  We've done naught since arriving but make do.  And that's something, no question - there's them as don't make do, and they're on the streets or worse now.  But I can't keep my thoughts from straying to what's next, what's beyond the horizon.  Am I merely to be a fishmonger?  That's not what my kin back home paid their blood for.  I do feel something taking shape within me.  I've not the slightest idea what to do with it when it's done, but that's something to worry about another day.

I'm going to need some more paper, I think.

Forgive the sloppy writing.  Have had considerable to drink, and I think I'm right entitled.  I've been through hell and back this evening, and I do not mean that figuratively.  I have seen hell.  It lies in my own heart, treacherous organ it's proven itself, time and again.  I have despaired.  Damn my eyes, I gave up tonight.

It's been an odd time, sure enough.  I've not dwelt much on Mum, but I believe that's due to my dwelling on little else for the entire voyage here.  Packed in tight, ankle deep in piss and vomit, it's hard not to take an account of one's life and think of what may've been.  The Mays that may have been.  And what the Mays may yet be.  Hell with it.  If Shakespeare can pun then so might I.  Rabbit seems sure Mum will find Da.  I believe her.  Rabbit sees things so much more than I.  I'm frightened of what that lass will become, sometimes, when I let myself dwell on it.

We've arrived in America to find slammed doors and snotty salesmen.  No one is pleased to see the Irish, it seems, and I wonder what it ever was we did to warrant such hatred.  We might as well be Jews.  We'd been living off the church since our arrival and I admit to a wee bit of guilt over it - we've some money, which is a sight more than most here.  But if we can't support ourselves there's no use for forty-odd dollars; may as well drink it away and spend it on fancy hats.  Then the fateful confession, Rabbit's first.

I fretted, I'll admit - downtown Brooklyn doesn't seem right for a witch-burning somehow, but there's a first time for everything, sure enough.  But it came and went, and then it was my turn, and the Father told me to speak to Sister Margaret of the Hibernians.  Funny that.  So we were taken to a secret chamber deep beneath the bowels of the church and told of a secret order, one that apparently looks out for us errant sons and daughters of Eire.  We were given a package to take to some actor in the Bowery.  The bastards could have told us to expect trouble.  Seemed simple enough.  That should've warned me right there.  Nothing's ever simple for our family nor for our kind, is it?

Policemen followed us.  Two of them.  We split up, hoping to lose them, and I was caught.  Too easily, I was caught.  I was caught and I was beaten down, but that's not what shamed me.  I brought forth every impulse of my heart, I called upon the memory of my father to give me strength, I even prayed, and nothing availed nor aided me, and I failed, but that is not what shamed me.  I gave up.  We beat starvation and death at every turn, and all it took was the same old oppressor in a different-coloured uniform with a knee on my back to break me, just for an instant, and I don't know if I only thought it or said it out loud...but my heart said it:  'There's nothing I can do'.

And then, salvation, in the form of Father Declan.  Who has now been an English priest, a starving Irishman, and a stately native New Yorker with a fine top hat and waxed mustachio.  Unlike many people of my acquaintance, I cannot explain away the eldritch when it smacks me in the face; though I fear I am descending into madness, I know what it was that I saw.  He laid a weir on that policeman, a curse that buckled his knees and undid his tendons, and gave me back the Hibernian package as nice as you please.  And then left me alone in the rat's alley where the dead men lost their bones, alone with the helpless copper, and me with three keen knives strapped to my sides.

Part of me thinks that what happened next should stay between myself, the policeman, and god.  But it's fitting I remember.  I exulted in his weakness.  He was every redcoat in that instant, every landlord, every bloody proper gentleman with a stick up his arse that won't hire Irish.  I could already feel his hot, hot blood flowing over my hands.  I don't know what my face looked like in that instant, but the cop's eyes went wide and he blurted, 'I have a daughter'.  I think those words saved him.  Me too, most like.  I wonder, now, if he was lying to me...not that it makes a difference, truly.  The man invoked family.  I will not cross that boundary.

I pushed his face down in the mud.  I made him tell me with knife and word who sent him after us, but I did not harm him, just in case he told true.  But I told him this:  'And how does it feel to be the one face down in the muck with a knee on your back and a knife at your throat?  You know all about our kind, do you?  Well, now I know all about you.  I'd be careful, if I were you, about who I take orders from in the future.  Now get up and go home to your daughter - if you even have one'.

Proud speech.  You'd almost think I wasn't furiously trying to keep my dinner down.  The package got delivered, my sisters made it back safe, all's well, I may as well sing a fecking ballad and do a little jig.  But my soul, it's not right.  I'm in turmoil.  I'm on the cusp of something, I feel it.  I felt it in the alley.  Something in me.  The glow, the spark, like that old woman in Galway said.  Something...something powerful.  I'll master it.  I will.  And I shall never, never, never, never despair again.  I swear it by my father's name and my own blood.  

[Ed. note:  The rest of this page is streaked with what preliminary testing has confirmed to be human blood.  Rather more than is safe; however if Mays' statements regarding his inebriated state are accurate, it is likely that the anti-coagulating properties of alcohol combined with a certain loss of manual dexterity would lead to such a volume.]

America is not what I thought it'd be.  Not that I had the slightest notion.  These past weeks - months, years - it's hard to look ahead.  When you're starving, and then again when you're theiving, you live moment by moment.  Some last an eternity.

Trip was horrid.  Must remember to stop thinking I know all there is to know about squalor - if I had to smell the stench of illness and shite in the workhouse, well, that's better than sleeping in it, now isn't it?  It was two days ago we came on land and already the voyage seems a feverish dream, half remembered.  My sisters were so strong.  I worried after Siobhan, plague was no small matter on the ship, but she made it through well enough.  She's not well, mind, but then again I doubt she ever will be.  Darcy Worthington.  If I ever get my hands on you, you poxy son of a whorehopper...

I've just realized that I never learnt the name of the ship that brought us here.  Wish I had.  Like forgetting the name of your mother - we were cooped up in the dark and wet for weeks, and then spewed out into the bright world in a great nasty flood.  Like being born again.  Mother.  I knew she was going to do it, I just knew.  Why didn't I say anything?  Ah, I hoped I was wrong, I suppose.  And there's iron in that lady.  No point worrying my sisters, I suppose.  

I wonder where Ian is now.  I wonder if he'd be proud.  Sometimes I can almost feel him looking over my shoulder, grinning in that bemused way of his.  If things were different...aye, there's the rub, I suppose.

More later.  Hands cramping - Rabbit's birthday present almost finished.

[Ed. note: While there were evidently several entries in these two years, several seem to have been torn out, while others were scratched out in ink.  One in particular was imperfectly concealed, and is here reproduced.  Style comparisons with unknown poets in 19th Century Galway are currently underway.]


She laughs.  Starvation and plague walk the land
As gaunt dogs red-coated, no hope, no soul;
And yet my bonnie Britt laughs on the strand
Which winds its weary way to workhouse hole.
Her shining copper tresses hail the sun,
Her eyes, the grey of storm-wracked seas, then shine.
A savagery to my traitor heart done,
Grievous and precious, horrid and fine

Is what you have done to me:
For a moment I had thee - 
For an instant I was free.

Happy sixteenth birthday, then, Will.  

It's been a strange time.  Understatement, that.  Our lot got worse and worse, and then a miracle happened.  

That blasted old cow Worthington evicted us.  Turned us out without a by-your-leave, after Siobhan sacrificed her health on the altar of those two Formorians she calls sons, after not paying my sister the wages she's due and making her walk, alone, in this day and age, from Castlebar home to Shannen.  Foul, inconstant woman.  An hour alone with her and her get and a thumb press, and I'd be a happy man indeed.

We walked the road to Castlebar, taking with us only what we could carry.  Siobhan came the closest to thawing I've seen her for some time when we had to leave her hope chest behind.  Don't rightly know what the fuss is, it's been empty for well on a year now.  Don't rightly know who'd marry the battle-axe anyhow.  Ah, now, that was uncharitable of me - she's some unusual talents, as I've found, and she's not without kindness.  And she's to thank for the one stroke of luck we've had since Seamus was took.  I'll be sure to do penance for that thought later.

The workhouses in Castlebar were full so we had to make our way to Galway.  The air's different in a port town...not just the smell nor the wet.  It's the way the waves crash just outside your hearing day and night, and the sea-borne wind tugs at your sleeve like an eager child, as though to say, "Come, come - there's something wondrous just beyond the horizon!"  'Course, it's only this past little while I've had time or vigor for such reflection.  The workhouse is all I ever need to know of hell.  Hell's not firey - it's grey.  It's cold, and it's hunger, and the smell of shite and pus every way you turn, and the same round of drudgery every day.  And then one day Siobhan of all of us found a way out.  She happened upon the Worthington's cook in the food line and was delivered to a secret kitchen in the heart of Galway, and to which she's brought us.

And here we've been since, under the rule of Finnis the robber-king and his man Toby, the duke of thieves, thugs and ne'er-do-wells.  I've taken a shine to the two of them - Finnis for his politics and Toby for his blessed malice.  Warms my heart to hear someone curse the Queen out loud, it does.  My sisters have proven themselves an able pair of footpads - Siobhan knows the secret places of the homes of the rich, and Rabbit is quicker than her namesake.  I'm able enough myself, I suppose.  My heart's not really in it.  Time was I'd be all a-tingle at the chance to dare all and win through.  And earning real, rich food is no small matter.  But what have we gained, truly?  We're not to steal anything we're not told to, and all we take goes to our patron.  If we kept the lucre from even one of our family outings we'd be in a good situation for years.  We have clothes on our backs and meat in our bellies, and that's riches sure enough, but - I want more, by all that's holy.  If I had a halfpenny for every library I've seen this year that those fattened bastards keep - for decoration, mind, not for the knowledge locked away within...I want those books.  I want them so badly I shake now when I walk into one of those places.  I want to talk to - no, I shouldn't name that desire.

Ah, be damned with it.  If a man can't dream on his birthday, when can he?  I've seen Britt.  Bonnie Britt McGee, from home.  I haven't the words for how seeing her undoes me.  I...ah, I could go on, but I'm not in the mood to be sticking daggers in my own heart just now.  I love her and I can't ever speak to her, for I would tell her everything and I can't.  I have to keep my family safe.

Damn it.

I feel a right coward just now.  I know in my heart of hearts that there wasn't anything to do about what happened to Seamus, but still.  Reason'll say what it will, but Passion has its own ways.  They trooped into our house, the fecking dogs, looking for "the traitor James May".  And then they took Seamus away, to torture and death, I don't doubt.  I keep thinking, had I been more clever, more brave, I could have said something to stop them taking him.  Done something.  I should at least have said somthing in Dad's defence - branded a traitor to a throne he never swore to serve.  Well.  Not that I know of.  Old Dad's history seems to be a wee bit more of a tangled skein than I ever gave him credit for.

We'll survive somehow, that I know.  We've come too far not to.  But I fear greatly.  I'm sure it's a sin on my head to be fretting about the food he brought in while the poor man's languishing in a cell, or dead already, for all I know.  But my life is not my own.  He gave himself that we might live, and I mean to honor that.  I have to worry about right here, right now, and keep the breath in my family.  Somehow.

I'd near forgotten this thing existed.  Haven't had a lot to say, mind - I find when I'm writing away I tend to get a little more introspective and cynical than I like, and I can ill afford that sort of thought these days.  Last harvest was totally ruined, every potato rotted to the core still in the earth.  Wasn't just us, turned out.  Everywhere.  At least, everywhere that matters.  I hear they've taken to calling it the Great Famine.  High and mighty words, I suppose, but accurate enough.  I've seen hale and hearty men turn to sniveling starvelings before my very eyes, these dark months.  Lucky for me I didn't have any bulk to miss.  It's got bad enough that a grown man will attack a child for food, and then you have to shoot him in the belly and run away, never knowing if he's dead or not.  Beginning to repeat on me, that is.  Not knowing whether men of my aquaintance are dead or not.  It's starting to haunt me a little, I think.

It's real.  All of it.  Begging the question of what is real, exactly, ha ha.  Apparently the unreal can be real and start asking for my life.  Walking into a glade and coming out of a forest?  Faerie tales.  

Well, yes.  Exactly.

I don't know that I'll ever find out what my father was up to all those years.  Mum or Seamus either, come to that.  I almost don't want to know.  But I said that I did, didn't I.  Well, come to that, I'd like to know what's going on but I'd rather not be dragged screaming into it like I was.  It's not the same.  I wanted to know, not get involved.  I know only enough of their ways to get me killed or worse.  Straddling two worlds, I am.  Like the Colossus.  I have to somehow be a bridge between the world that Siobhan lives in and the one that Rabbit lives in and I'm torn in two.  

God, I'd take the cup from her lips if it were allowed me.  She's too young for this.  Come to that, I'm too young for this.  I think I'm getting old before my time, me.  A weeklong trip, no, a fecking quest, and I shot a man, and I kept us safe and dry from the Church to the Circle and back again, and does anyone thank me?  Does anyone tell me I've done well to get myself and Rabbit there and back again with body and soul still knit together?  Didn't I do right?

I sound ungrateful.  Maybe I am at that.  It's that old man got me thinking about such things.  I told that man more about myself and made more wishes in his hearing than is wise on a journey like that what I was on.  Ah, now I'm just jumping at shadows.  Half mad with fatigue, most like.  The world will make more sense in the morning.  And if it doesn't, well...at least time will be steadily taking me further away from three days ago.
Father is alive.  Tight lipped old bastard won't let anything else slip, but father is alive.  That's something, all right.  Something to hold onto.

Siobhan is dying, Ian hasn't come back, Rabbit is acting stranger than usual and I've got a priest in my house once a day, and I can't do a bloody thing about bloody any of it.  I just wish it were all over.  I'm so tired.

Siobhan is not well.  Nothing is well.  I have failed my father's last task and I have failed my family.  And the worst of it is that I've not the slightest clue of what I might've done different.

Ian and I got back yesterday.  Our barn was full of English horses and our kitchen was full of English asses, strutting about like they owned the bloody place.  Asked me some questions and left.  It was then I heard the coughing from the bedroom, saw that Rabbit was shaking with rage and Mum had more creases on her forehead than a few muddy footprints could rightly account for.  I went, I looked.  Half Siohan's face is swollen up to twice it's usual size.  Didn't sound quite in her right mind.  I think that's what gave me most pause.  Siohan's always in her right mind, come hell or high waters.  She told me she was kicked by a horse.  She must think I'm a feckin' idiot.

'Course, I suppose I am an idiot for trying to feed the same line to Ian.  He went into one of his silences.  That worried me.  Ian's not a quick nor a practiced hand at thinking, but when he does you can almost hear the gears grinding together.  Slow and thorough and powerful.  Rabbit told me to my face that Siobhan was lying.  I just told her that I knew and we'd talk about it later.

This morning Ian wasn't in his bed, and an English is dead, hung by the neck and bound with holly.  

I cannot be thinking what I'm thinking.  It's not sane and it's not right but it is what it is and what am I supposed to do now?  I couldn't feed us all with Ian's help and now he's gone.  I know he's not coming back.  I know it.  I feel it in my waters, whatever he's done (or had done to him, but I won't, I am not thinking that) there's no coming back from.
Harvest's done.  Hands hurt.  Maybe one half to a quarter of last year, but might be we'll make it.  Leaving for Castlebar in a few.
